Soul Destruction

Soul Destruction refers to the destruction of atman by force of will, consumption by hunger, digestion in a Soul Gigerium or soul cauldron, or by other means.

Consumption

A hunger leaches mana from another atman without damaging the enrichment of the victim, though such a victim may still be destroyed if it does not produce mana more quickly than the parasite takes it. Such a destruction is referred to as consumption.

Leaching of a soul leading toward final consumption may be a swift and silent or slow and subtle experience.

Digestion

Soul Gigerium and soul cauldrons are two physical constructions which function in a very similar way, leaching mana from an atman similarly to a hunger, and feeding it into some receptacle - often another atman. While digestion in this manner harms the enrichment of the atman digested, eventually depriving it of its ability to produce enough mana to sustain itself, it does not serve to enrich the receptacle.

The digestion of a soul is a painful and deeply traumatising experience at any rate.

Obliteration

Obliteration refers to the instantaneous destruction of an atman and release of all stored mana. It is a violent phenomenon from which it is difficult to harvest the resultant energy.

In Magic Rituals

While many forms of arcane ritual requiring the sacrifice of living beings require only the mana release of bodily destruction, the most potent may seek that released by obliteration of a soul instead. In the case of faux divine rituals - those which appeal to some higher power, likely an evil outsider in this case - it is likely that souls exchanged in the ritual are required to be transferred directly to the source of the power, to do with as it pleases, rather than destroyed in any way during the ritual itself.
